verdict.summary: During docker push, some layers already exist in the remote registry. This is normal behavior for unchanged layers, but can cause issues when pushes hang or fail midway.

dead_ends.action: Rebuilding the entire image with --no-cache to force new layers
dead_ends.why_fails: Creates entirely new layers that must all be re-uploaded, wasting bandwidth and time without fixing the actual push issue

dead_ends.action: Deleting remote repository and re-pushing everything
dead_ends.why_fails: Destroys all existing tags and digests; other consumers of the image will break

workarounds.action: Simply retry the push — existing layers will be skipped efficiently
workarounds.how: docker push <image>:<tag> — Docker will skip layers that already exist and only upload new ones
workarounds.condition: when the push was interrupted midway

workarounds.action: Check registry storage quotas if push fails after layer-exists messages
workarounds.how: Verify registry disk space and storage limits; some registries reject new manifests when quota is exceeded even though layers exist
workarounds.condition: when push completes layer upload but fails on manifest

leads_to.condition: when token expires during a long push operation

preceded_by.condition: when a previous push timed out leaving partial layers

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Layer already exists is during push and is usually benign (layer is in the registry), while layer already being pulled is during pull and indicates a concurrent download
